[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A small rectangular transparisteel viewport provides a view out
the front of the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for
the large starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the
viewport is the main control board, providing essential functions like the
shipwide power lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up
and folded back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses
overhead as needed. There is not really enough room for anyone to comfortably
stand here; there is only room for the pilot's chair and the controls arranged
around it. Most of the space aboard the small shuttle is dedicated to cargo.
Lights overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in space.
You see a bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Starseekers", a wormhole
drive tracer, a glossy silvery gray ceramic felo chow bowl, and a silky cerulean
cushion decorated with embroidered dark red dragons here.
You can go south and out.
[Newbie Help] Bryan Stout transmits, "Yes what everyone has said here. It
doesn't have to be super complicated. You can always talk to staff later to see
how your character is doing in their eyes, see if your style of play could
change in any way to reflect your profile, etc. Patience is key. It's also very
rewarding in the end."
[Newbie Help] Squidmind transmits, "Believe me, we really don't want it to be
complicated. Profiles are an incredibly huge timesink, which is a big reason we
added in one sentence concepts for approval first. If your profile is
approaching 500 words, you probably need to refocus. Personality is all we
really care about, how we can espect your character to react to the various
forms of drama and plot that are common in this game."

begin with.  As for helping someone refine theirs, asking them questions is the

[MTTS] davetaylor: Liking playing music doesn't tell us how you might react in
RP situations, for instance, when you hate somebody and it's very obvious.
[MTTS] rosey: My feedback seems to confuse me even more because it often seemed
I did nothing right.
[MTTS] Carroll: I am good at creative writing but not the way its asked for
here.
[MTTS] usfolks: So if you like music, making music, and entertaining people,
while you can roleplay that, it shouldn't be because it's what you want.
[MTTS] Butchulla: Something like that is definitely something I'd attend. I'm
all for trying to help people.
[MTTS] Carroll: Sorry what do you mean its not supposed to be the way you want?
[MTTS] rosey: That is a good example of a confusing comment, who would not do
something because they want.
[MTTS] nadira: Yes, a forum about profiles and character concepts sounds like a
good idea, and that I would like to attend.
[MTTS] rosey: I do it in real life.
[MTTS] Carroll: That is stifling a person's spirit and creativity.
[MTTS] usfolks: My char has some likes and dislikes, personality traits, very
much opposite to who I ame. Because if I come here and I play myself, even at a
different age, gender, race, and period in time, that is not roleplaying.
[MTTS] Squidmind: Sometimes it's as simple as just explaining why the character
does something.  'My character plays music for people' doesn't tell us anything
about the character, just an action they take.  If you explain what motivates
them to take that action, it has a better chance of showing the thought process
of the character.  And I don't mean 'i want to entertain them', because that's
not the full picture either.
Proper in-sector coordinates not reached.  AutoVector program aborted.
[MTTS] usfolks: Because of that, my char gets on my nerves at times. I can't
stand the person they are...because they are not me and I wouldn't be friends
with them. But that makes it better RP. Don't play who you are, play the
character you want to play, yes. But don't make them like to do something
because you like to do it. Then you're just being you in a space game and not
roleplaying at all.
[MTTS] alc_71: The best advice I can give you is learn separation. I was
terrible with it for awhile and have worked hard to become better. Separating
yourself from the character is key. The character concept will give you more
time to sort out the profile. I do wish that were available when I was trying to
write mine.
[MTTS] Squidmind: Carroll: I think what usfolks is trying to say there is that
there needs to be a disconnect between the player and the character.  If the
character is doing something just because that's what the player would do in
that situation, that's not roleplaying, that's the player being the player.  It
leads to the removal of the IC/OOC divide and creates OOC issues.
[MTTS] usfolks: Yes Squid, thanks. I'm doing too many things at once and not
explaining myself too well I guess.
[MTTS] Carroll: If that is the way I want to play, that is my choice, in fact
its good to play yourself in another world it stretches your thinking and
imagination.
[MTTS] rosey: But how can staff know if I am doing that or not, they do not know
me oocly.
[MTTS] Squidmind: Except it doesn't, at all.  If you're being you, then you're
not roleplaying.  You're responding to events as you, the player, would.  Which
WILL lead to OOC problems, because we see it on a regular basis.
[MTTS] rosey: For all they know, in real life I hate music.
[MTTS] Carroll: To me roleplay is like entering into a book and feeling chars
doing their actions even if you have a hint of yourself.
[MTTS] alc_71: For example, let's say you have had four characters. They all
behave very similarly, staff is going to figure out that you are playing
yourself easy enough.
[MTTS] rosey: The type of character I am trying to make is different from any
others I have had.
[MTTS] usfolks: A lot of times they can tell. And yes, they see how we react. I
reacted oocly to a decision my chari made mecause I have the same flaw as they
do. Somehow I managed not to avoid. There's no way we can be opposite our char,
but we can make enough things different and do our actions on behalf of them,
and not on behalf of ourselves. When you start doing that, you tend to get hurt,
frustrated, and worse.
[MTTS] Squidmind: Rosey: That's fine.  But liking or disliking music doesn't
actually have anything to do with the character concept or their personality.
[MTTS] Carroll: And the tropes are so stifling to me!
[MTTS] nadira: Well, lots of people, including myself, who have played on this
game for a longer time, can tell you exactly why being yourself only hurts you
in the end. What if the story your character ends up in is too confronting to
you, comes too close to reality? I have spent months feeling really bad because
things related to a previous character were too close to who I am, and it had
made me, the player, feel depressed. No one needs that.
[MTTS] usfolks: Tropes are there fore a reason. They're overused. If you can
find a way to use one in a creative way and explain yourself, you might get
lucky.
[MTTS] usfolks: Also apparently my typing skills are sucking today. Apologies.
[MTTS] rosey: This is why I think it would be fun to just play to roleplay and

[MTTS] rosey: But I would need credits to do that too.
[MTTS] alc_71: I try to find things for my character to like that I dislike or
vice versa. Like I will never create a character who is into aspects my real
line of work. Also, smaller things like you may love beer and your character be
strongly against drinking alcohol. It does help with the separation.
[MTTS] Squidmind: The profile is there to help you roleplay, it's not a method

course.

[MTTS] Carroll: There are far to many good people out there that truly want to

[MTTS] Squidmind: The biggest reason for not playing yourself is always the fact
that if you're playing a character that isn't you, there's a distance between
the actions taken and you.  So when other characters and the game world react
negatively to your actions, you don't feel OOCly terrible.  But if you're just
you, you're going to feel pretty bad in real life because they're not saying
'that character did something dumb', they're saying 'YOU did something dumb'.
The starship transitions into another sector.
The starship transitions into another sector.
The starship transitions into another sector.

[MTTS] Squidmind: It says that in the world of SC, the majority of people do not
specifically have a faith.  The minority of people who have some form of faith
are part of a religion that comprises of the various extant religions that over
the past 300 years converged into a singular overarching framework that became
known as His Chosen Path.
[MTTS] usfolks: It doesn't say that there is a lack of religion anywhere. But
they do try to discourage people from playing a religous character because
unless it's done right, it can end in proselytizing in the game, which we don't
want.
The starship transitions into another sector.
[MTTS] Squidmind: Even in the real world, populations have become increasingly
secular over the past 70+ years worldwide, this is just our interpretation of a
continuation of that.

[MTTS] Squidmind: We actually did have a very religious player a few years ago

playing the player.  This resulted in a situation where a character in a world
whose overarching religion was all about personal choices and not trying to
convert people... tried to convert people in-game and got very, very angry OOCly
when the game world did not support their efforts to turn the game their
particular religion.

[MTTS] Squidmind: Basically, this is a sci fi space opera game about spaceships
and aliens, it's not really the right place to have an in-depth discussion
(whether roleplayed or real life) about religion.  Hence our creation of 'His
Chosen Path', which basically boils down to 'in the end everyone wants to get
along and after 300 years they kinda do, at least religion-wise'.

[MTTS] Squidmind: I think it depends on what you want from a show.  If you like
cheesy optimistic space opera, TOS all the way.  If you like progressive
optimistic philosophy, TNG.  If you want a dark, vaguely religious, vaguely
shades of grey overarching plot, go DS9.  Voyager has like three good episodes,
so I can't really recommend it.   Enterprise is also hard to recommend, but I
love Shran.

[MTTS] Squidmind: As for OOC asides, keep in mind that we do our best to
separate 'Stop doing X' from 'If you keep doing X, Y will happen.'  The latter
means you are welcome to continue, but with the player knowledge that there will
be consequences.  Consequences are vital for good roleplay, both negative and
positive.

aside when they don't want it than NOT give them one when they would have
preferred it.

[MTTS] Squidmind: There are two ways to create a character - the first is you
start with the concept and play it, the second is you start playing and then
craft the concept in that early period.  Both are valid here, because you can
enter the game as a cadet, whose IC existence is in a state of flux until the
profile is approved.
[MTTS] usfolks: This is not real life, Rosey. This is roleplay.

[MTTS] usfolks: That is you being you in a different setting.
[MTTS] Squidmind: And that's a perfectly valid form of roleplay in some places. 
Just not here.  Different places will expect different things from roleplay.  If
you want a consistent game world, you need consistent characters to inhabit that
world.
[MTTS] valiant8086: Your personality is not wanted in the concept, not really as
far as I understand.
[MTTS] Butchulla: Yeah. That's amazing that points thing. We had 25 in each
category. So you guys are lucky. You have way more time to feel out the game.
[MTTS] Squidmind: The concept is a single summation of the character.  If you
had to describe someone in a single sentence, how would you do it?  How would
you describe Elon Musk?  Adolf Hitler?  Superman?  David Bowie?
[MTTS] Squidmind: Adolf Hitler loved dogs, played with kids, was an artist.  But
does that tell us anything about his personality?  No.
[MTTS] usfolks: Here's the thing. You can use this as an escape, sure. But Rosey
is playing Rosey in the future, that is not roleplaying. If Carroll is playing
Carroll in the future, that is not roleplaying. That is being you in a different
setting. In order to be able to decide how your char will react on a consistent
basis, you have to have something set out that will determine that. My char does
things that drive me up the wall. Because my char has a background very
different to mine. But if I just went with my imagination and played how I
would...I wouldn't be roleplaying at all.
[MTTS] Carroll: David would be a good musician adolph woudl be a bad man to

[MTTS] Squidmind: Neither of those define either of those people.

[MTTS] Squidmind: 'musician' and 'bad man' can apply to millions of people.
[MTTS] davetaylor: Key things about these people are things like how they go

[MTTS] Squidmind: One example for Hitler might be 'A charismatic bigot who wants
to restore his nation's glory by vilifying those different to him.'  You have
aspects of 'bad man' there, but there's enough to separate him from everyone
else who does bad things.  You see a tiny aspect of the drive he has.  For
Bowie, maybe 'A confused man who spent his life trying to find himself through
the art he created.'
[MTTS] Squidmind: Yeah, Carroll's second example was a lot closer.
[MTTS] Squidmind: Basically, what defines the character as a person?  What is
the core of them?
[MTTS] Squidmind: We're not asking for a fully fleshed out three dimensional
entire life of a person, that would be ridiculous. But we want something that
makes it appear as if that life could exist.
[MTTS] rosey: In real life I am limited in what I can do and am allowed to do
from others and from consequences and so some of that stuff I would like to do
in the game, I like to play with the pupppets and music instruments here.
[MTTS] usfolks: When that character concept came out, I sat down and wrote one
for my char. And then I went, ok, how would I have changed his profile based on
this? I think I would have been able to write that profile a lot better the
first time if I'd had that concept of who I (always) wanted him to be if I'd
started with the concept first. And like Dave, I've gone back and looked at my
profile. And that profile has allowed me to have some amazing RP opportunities,
thanks to hosts. They helped me with events (based off the profile) that have
made the char so much more real.
[MTTS] Squidmind: I am sorry to hear that there are things you are limited in
doing and disallowed from doing in real life, rosey.  However, this game is not
really focused on playing musical instruments and playing with puppets, nor are
either of those a character concept.
[MTTS] rosey: In feedback on my profiles I have also been told that flying ships
and doint pilot stuff is not all there is either so how do I kow how I can put
in a profile.
[MTTS] rosey: Know.
[MTTS] valiant8086: Play as a cadet for a while and find out?
[MTTS] usfolks: It's a combination. Life isn't just your job. Your personality
isn't your job.
[MTTS] davetaylor: Stuff about what you're like in groups, how you deal with
conflict, are you ambitious, laid back, argumentative, do you keep quiet or
speak without thinking, so many things you can talk about.
[MTTS] rosey: I have done that and kknow the game quite well.
[MTTS] Squidmind: Flying ships and 'doing pilot stuff' is basically the job of
the character.  It doesn't add anything to the profile because you're describing
game mechanics, not a personality.  If you mean that you say in the profile that
your character wants to fly ships and 'do pilot stuff', that also doesn't add to
the -character-, because the character is the why, not the what.

[MTTS] rosey: How about this as a concept? Dorothy is a girl who is tired of the
mundane life she is used to and whishes to spread her wings?
[MTTS] Squidmind: It's better than talking about starships or playing the piano,
but it still suffers from the same basic issue. It doesn't describe who Dorothy
is or separate her from all the other people who are tired of their mundane
lives and want to spread their wings.  What makes her any different to them?
[MTTS] rosey: Hmm let me use my imagination.
[MTTS] Squidmind: But you're definitely on the right track.
[MTTS] rosey: Thanks.
[MTTS] Carroll: Carroll is a confused girl trying to find herself and in time
learns to somehow free herself and find knowledge, adventure and personal
growth.
[MTTS] Carroll: Since there are so many tropes what am I allowed to do?
[MTTS] Squidmind: That one isn't so good.  You've copied the first half of the
Bowie concept but haven't actually got the meaningful part, you just have a bit
where you talk about a vague future.
[MTTS] Squidmind: You still haven't explained what you mean by tropes and
'allowed to do'.
[MTTS] Carroll: I mean the many tropes that are mentioned in the help file, I
mean I cannot be an explorer, or comr from a poor background or from a farming
background, etc etc.
[MTTS] usfolks: Carroll, tropes are just that because they're overused and
overused. Everyone wants to have a tragic past where they were left alone at a
young age on a farm because the Outsiders killed their parents (who happened to
be famous). If you can find a way to make a trope not tropish...then try it.
Tropes are not an absolute no. You just have to find a way to make them not so
common.
[MTTS] Squidmind: None of those things should define a person.  They are
forbidden tropes because people tried to use them as a replacement for actually
putting in a character.
[MTTS] Carroll: Sinc ehtere are so many, hwo would I flesh even the vauge
concepts I had just put out nhere?
[MTTS] Carroll: Er mistyping.
[MTTS] Carroll: I meant since there are so many, hwo can I flesh out the vague
concepts and even make a good profile.
[MTTS] Squidmind: There are nineteen examples in the forbidden tropes help file.
 Do you really think there are only nineteen possible character archetypes or
personalities in the world?  Most of those forbidden tropes don't actually have
anything to do with the character at all, but events in-game or family history.
[MTTS] usfolks: As an example, there is a country bumpkin whose dead relative
was a pilot and has a politician parent. However, while they are tropes, they
were done in a way that didn't follow exactly as others had used them. So they
made it through. Be creative. Don't use what everyone else has.
[MTTS] usfolks: These things also do not define said character. They are but a
tiny bit of the history.
[MTTS] usfolks: Ok, maybe the country bumpkin does...
[MTTS] Squidmind: If your profile is 'I lived on a farm, my parents were farmers
and did farmer things, I did farmer things, then I became a pilot.'  How does
that tell us anything about that character?  They know how to plough a field? 
That's a skill, not part of their personality.
[MTTS] davetaylor: Why become a pilot given how people feel about pilots?
[MTTS] rosey: I thought you did not want personality in concept.
[MTTS] Squidmind: Rosey: Carroll specifically mentioned the profile, so I
responded to that.
[MTTS] usfolks: The tropes shouldn't play a part in concept at all, even if you
find a way to make them work.
[MTTS] rosey: Oh.
[MTTS] Squidmind: Basically, the why is always more important than the what. 
The what can give context, but without the why is entirely useless.
[MTTS] rosey: Even in real life I would have problems explaining why I do what I
do.
[MTTS] rosey: Sometimes.
[MTTS] usfolks: We all do sometimes. But can you explain why you are (in
general) the way you are? Not individual actions, but your general persona?
[MTTS] rosey: Not really.
[MTTS] rosey: Maybe to a certain extent.
[MTTS] rosey: For example I have an anger problem in RL that I would say I got

glossy red ceramic felo chow bowl, and an early warning space defense device
here.
You can go enter into the ship.
You float close to the luxury sightseer "Celestial Explorer", open the hatch,
and carefully float inside, orienting yourself so that your feet hit the floor
as you enter the ship's artificial gravity field.
cycle
You press a large button marked CYCLE.
enter
You may not leave the airlock while it is cycling.
A small light on the airlock control panel turns from red to yellow. Through
your suit, you gradually begin to hear the hiss of air entering the airlock.
The hiss of air slowly fades away into nothingness, and the yellow light becomes
green.
enter

drive tracer, a glossy silvery gray ceramic felo chow bowl, and a silky cerulean
cushion decorated with embroidered dark red dragons here.
You can go south and out.

[Outside Celestial Explorer]
You float above the starship's brightly-shining hull, which at this distance
blocks off a large portion of your view of space.  The glint of stars reflects
from the hull.  The reflection is occasionally distorted by various weapons
scars or pockmarks.

[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A small rectangular transparisteel viewport provides a view out
the front of the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for
the large starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the
viewport is the main control board, providing essential functions like the
shipwide power lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up
and folded back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses
overhead as needed. There is not really enough room for anyone to comfortably
stand here; there is only room for the pilot's chair and the controls arranged
around it. Most of the space aboard the small shuttle is dedicated to cargo.
Lights overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in space.
You see a bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Starseekers", a wormhole
drive tracer, a glossy silvery gray ceramic felo chow bowl, and a silky cerulean
cushion decorated with embroidered dark red dragons here.
You can go south and out.
[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A small rectangular transparisteel viewport provides a view out
the front of the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for
the large starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the
viewport is the main control board, providing essential functions like the
shipwide power lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up
and folded back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses
overhead as needed. There is not really enough room for anyone to comfortably
stand here; there is only room for the pilot's chair and the controls arranged
around it. Most of the space aboard the small shuttle is dedicated to cargo.
Lights overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in space.
You see a bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Starseekers", a wormhole
drive tracer, a glossy silvery gray ceramic felo chow bowl, and a silky cerulean
cushion decorated with embroidered dark red dragons here.

[Deep Space]
The vacuum of space seems oddly peaceful now that it surrounds you. It is not
deep black as you expected, but seems to be filled with a diffuse glow. Stars
glint all around you, stunningly bright and sharp with no atmosphere or
vacuum-protected glass to distort their light. A wide smear of stars fills one
area of the sky, pointing the way Coreward.
You see a bit of oddly-designed optical wiring here.
You can go in any direction using a spacejet.
You are weightless here.

glossy red ceramic felo chow bowl, and an early warning space defense device
here.
You can go enter into the ship.
You float close to the luxury sightseer "Celestial Explorer", open the hatch,
and carefully float inside, orienting yourself so that your feet hit the floor
as you enter the ship's artificial gravity field.
[0m[Miriani] Kitty Mars leans in toward you and gently kisses your lips.[0m
cycle
You press a large button marked CYCLE.
A small light on the airlock control panel turns from red to yellow. Through
your suit, you gradually begin to hear the hiss of air entering the airlock.
enter
You may not leave the airlock while it is cycling.
The hiss of air slowly fades away into nothingness, and the yellow light becomes
green.
The computer announces, "Cycling complete."

cushion decorated with embroidered dark red dragons here.

ftl 275
The computer announces, "Setting course to Artifact Beacon Alpha 275."
Something deep inside the starship roars to life as the lights dim sharply.
A wormhole suddenly appears in front of the ship, its edges tinged an unusual
deep purple. Strange undulating shapes are half-visible deep inside it.
A thick undulating mist suddenly seems to rush toward the starship from every
direction, quickly blotting out the stars. Random shapes, some half-familiar,
occasionally form in the mist only to disappear almost immediately.
[0m04:28[0m
The computer beeps in an imperative manner and informs you that the starship's
sensors have detected a new location of interest in the riftflow.
The starship has left a unique area of space.
A formless mist suddenly swirls outside the viewports, then is rapidly sucked
forward into a bright wormhole in front of the ship. The wormhole blinks out of
existence, and the ship is suddenly in normal space.
The computer announces, "Autotravel destination reached."
ships
There are no other ships in the sector.

wait.

players coming to the game!

l
[Starship "Happy"; Living Quarters]
This is a small room designed to give crew members a place to sleep while on
long journeys, and it isn't large enough to do much else. A long counter is
bolted to the wall opposite the entryway, and two narrow bunks have been bolted
to the two remaining walls. A small keypad is next to the door, controlling a
simple lock. The status lights overhead are currently not receiving power.
Looking through the windows, you see that the ship is at League Rapid Recharging
Eatery & Battery-Powered Rest Station; Docking Bay.

l
[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A small rectangular transparisteel viewport provides a view out
the front of the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for
the large starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the
viewport is the main control board, providing essential functions like the
shipwide power lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up
and folded back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses
overhead as needed. There is not really enough room for anyone to comfortably
stand here; there is only room for the pilot's chair and the controls arranged
around it. Most of the space aboard the small shuttle is dedicated to cargo. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is at League Rapid Recharging Eatery &
Battery-Powered Rest Station; Docking Bay.
You see a bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Starseekers", a wormhole
drive tracer, a glossy silvery gray ceramic felo chow bowl, and a silky cerulean
cushion decorated with embroidered dark red dragons here.
You can go south and out.

[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A small rectangular transparisteel viewport provides a view out
the front of the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for
the large starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the
viewport is the main control board, providing essential functions like the
shipwide power lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up
and folded back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses
overhead as needed. There is not really enough room for anyone to comfortably
stand here; there is only room for the pilot's chair and the controls arranged
around it. Most of the space aboard the small shuttle is dedicated to cargo.
Lights overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in space.
You see a bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Starseekers", a wormhole
drive tracer, a glossy silvery gray ceramic felo chow bowl, and a silky cerulean
cushion decorated with embroidered dark red dragons here.
You can go south and out.

[Deep Space]
The vacuum of space seems oddly peaceful now that it surrounds you. It is not
deep black as you expected, but seems to be filled with a diffuse glow. Stars
glint all around you, stunningly bright and sharp with no atmosphere or
vacuum-protected glass to distort their light. A wide smear of stars fills one
area of the sky, pointing the way Coreward.

[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Airlock]
You see a large secure xenology storage container, a row of flightlockers, a
glossy red ceramic felo chow bowl, and an early warning space defense device
here.
You can go enter into the ship.

and carefully float inside, orienting yourself so that your feet hit the floor
as you enter the ship's artificial gravity field.
cycle

mir
A small light on the airlock control panel turns from red to yellow. Through
your suit, you gradually begin to hear the hiss of air entering the airlock.
The hiss of air slowly fades away into nothingness, and the yellow light becomes
green.
The computer announces, "Cycling complete."

[0m#SESSION 'StarConquest' ACTIVATED.[0m
l
[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A small rectangular transparisteel viewport provides a view out
the front of the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for
the large starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the
viewport is the main control board, providing essential functions like the
shipwide power lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up
and folded back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses
overhead as needed. There is not really enough room for anyone to comfortably
stand here; there is only room for the pilot's chair and the controls arranged
around it. Most of the space aboard the small shuttle is dedicated to cargo.
Lights overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in space.
You see a bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Starseekers", a wormhole
drive tracer, a glossy silvery gray ceramic felo chow bowl, and a silky cerulean
cushion decorated with embroidered dark red dragons here.
You can go south and out.
[0m[Miriani] A high-capacity transparent Lore computer beeps quietly, indicating
that its TransLink tracking functionality has been activated.[0m
eta
The ship's current engine speed is 25000 km/s.
At that speed, the ship will arrive at its current autopilot destination in
about 7.2 seconds.

[Deep Space]
The vacuum of space seems oddly peaceful now that it surrounds you. It is not
deep black as you expected, but seems to be filled with a diffuse glow. Stars
glint all around you, stunningly bright and sharp with no atmosphere or
vacuum-protected glass to distort their light. A wide smear of stars fills one
area of the sky, pointing the way Coreward.
You see an intricately-decorated knife here.
You can go in any direction using a spacejet.
You are weightless here.

l
[Outside Celestial Explorer]
You float above the starship's brightly-shining hull, which at this distance
blocks off a large portion of your view of space.  The glint of stars reflects
from the hull.  The reflection is occasionally distorted by various weapons
scars or pockmarks.
You can go in any direction using a spacejet, or return to Celestial Explorer.
You are weightless here.
enter
[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Airlock]
You see a large secure xenology storage container, a row of flightlockers, a
glossy red ceramic felo chow bowl, and an early warning space defense device
here.
You can go enter into the ship.
You float close to the luxury sightseer "Celestial Explorer", open the hatch,
and carefully float inside, orienting yourself so that your feet hit the floor
as you enter the ship's artificial gravity field.
cycle
You press a large button marked CYCLE.
A small light on the airlock control panel turns from red to yellow. Through
your suit, you gradually begin to hear the hiss of air entering the airlock.
The hiss of air slowly fades away into nothingness, and the yellow light becomes
green.
enter

drive tracer, a glossy silvery gray ceramic felo chow bowl, and a silky cerulean
cushion decorated with embroidered dark red dragons here.
You can go south and out.

[Deep Space]
The vacuum of space seems oddly peaceful now that it surrounds you. It is not
deep black as you expected, but seems to be filled with a diffuse glow. Stars
glint all around you, stunningly bright and sharp with no atmosphere or
vacuum-protected glass to distort their light. A wide smear of stars fills one
area of the sky, pointing the way Coreward.
You see a section of what may once have been powered armor here.
You can go in any direction using a spacejet.
You are weightless here.

expandable telescoping xenology container.

[0m#SESSION 'StarConquest' ACTIVATED.[0m
enter
Board what?
l
[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A small rectangular transparisteel viewport provides a view out
the front of the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for
the large starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the
viewport is the main control board, providing essential functions like the
shipwide power lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up
and folded back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses
overhead as needed. There is not really enough room for anyone to comfortably
stand here; there is only room for the pilot's chair and the controls arranged
around it. Most of the space aboard the small shuttle is dedicated to cargo.
Lights overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in space.
You see a bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Starseekers", a wormhole
drive tracer, a glossy silvery gray ceramic felo chow bowl, and a silky cerulean
cushion decorated with embroidered dark red dragons here.
You can go south and out.
eta
The ship's current engine speed is 25000 km/s.
At that speed, the ship will arrive at its current autopilot destination in
about 6.2 seconds.

You press a button to cancel the current autopilot program.

ftl 275
The computer announces, "Setting course to Artifact Beacon Alpha 275."
Something deep inside the starship roars to life as the lights dim sharply.
A wormhole suddenly appears in front of the ship, its edges tinged an unusual
deep purple. Strange undulating shapes are half-visible deep inside it.
A thick undulating mist suddenly seems to rush toward the starship from every
direction, quickly blotting out the stars. Random shapes, some half-familiar,
occasionally form in the mist only to disappear almost immediately.
The starship has left a unique area of space.
The starship has entered a unique area of space.
Bits of starships of alien design and other assorted junk litter space in this
area. Oddly, judging from some of the debris that the ship can detect in the
distance, this was the site not only of a naval battle but of some sort of
space-based infantry engagement.
A formless mist suddenly swirls outside the viewports, then is rapidly sucked
forward into a bright wormhole in front of the ship. The wormhole blinks out of
existence, and the ship is suddenly in normal space.
The computer announces, "Autotravel destination reached."
ships
There are no other ships in the sector.

You see a large secure xenology storage container, a row of flightlockers, a

here.

your suit, you hear the hiss of air quickly leaving the airlock.
The hiss of air slowly fades away into nothingness, and the yellow light becomes
red.

[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Airlock]
You see a large secure xenology storage container, a row of flightlockers, a
glossy red ceramic felo chow bowl, and an early warning space defense device
here.
You can go enter into the ship.
You float close to the luxury sightseer "Celestial Explorer", open the hatch,
and carefully float inside, orienting yourself so that your feet hit the floor
as you enter the ship's artificial gravity field.
cycle
You press a large button marked CYCLE.
A small light on the airlock control panel turns from red to yellow. Through
your suit, you gradually begin to hear the hiss of air entering the airlock.
The hiss of air slowly fades away into nothingness, and the yellow light becomes
green.
The computer announces, "Cycling complete."

[MTTS] atherj: So hosts, since we have temp station modules for just about
everything, have you guys thought of adding a QE one, out of curiosity?
[MTTS] usfolks: I've wondered that too, but figured the price would end up being
quite prohibitive.
[MTTS] Butchulla: I'd imagine it would be, but it's a neat idea.
[MTTS] atherj: I mean, I suppose it depends on your goals.
[MTTS] usfolks: If they were to base the module off the price for a
ship-installed one, it would be what, 200 megacredits?
[MTTS] Ulias: A set of asteroid mining ones might be kinda neat too, though I'm
not sure how much it would actually get used. But it could be a set of them like
the salvage op ones.
[MTTS] atherj: Oh, I wouldn't necessarily base it off of all that. Most of them
aren't relaly based on that kind of pricing.
[MTTS] Ulias: A QE one would be pretty nice though for sure.
[MTTS] atherj: I would probably say something more along the lines of 24-25
megacredits.
[MTTS] Butchulla: I don't even wanna think about a module that would cost 200
megacredits.
[MTTS] atherj: For something like what is currently occurring with the
in-character expedition that people are on now, a QE module would've been an
interesting add-on.
[MTTS] usfolks: However, those chars do have easy access to a QE as it is.
[MTTS] Butchulla: Yeah, it would have.
[MTTS] atherj: They do, they do.
[MTTS] atherj: But.
[MTTS] atherj: Not all future ones necessarily would.

[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Airlock]

glossy red ceramic felo chow bowl, and an early warning space defense device

as you enter the ship's artificial gravity field.

[0m#SESSION 'StarConquest' ACTIVATED.[0m
l
[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A small rectangular transparisteel viewport provides a view out
the front of the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for
the large starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the
viewport is the main control board, providing essential functions like the
shipwide power lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up
and folded back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses
overhead as needed. There is not really enough room for anyone to comfortably
stand here; there is only room for the pilot's chair and the controls arranged
around it. Most of the space aboard the small shuttle is dedicated to cargo.
Lights overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in space.
You see a bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Starseekers", a wormhole
drive tracer, a glossy silvery gray ceramic felo chow bowl, and a silky cerulean
cushion decorated with embroidered dark red dragons here.
You can go south and out.

[0m[Miriani] Kitty Mars says, "i said to him, rogan ok dear friend, time for me to

l
[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A small rectangular transparisteel viewport provides a view out
the front of the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for
the large starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the
viewport is the main control board, providing essential functions like the
shipwide power lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up
and folded back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses
overhead as needed. There is not really enough room for anyone to comfortably
stand here; there is only room for the pilot's chair and the controls arranged
around it. Most of the space aboard the small shuttle is dedicated to cargo.
Lights overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in space.
You see a bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Starseekers", a wormhole
drive tracer, a glossy silvery gray ceramic felo chow bowl, and a silky cerulean
cushion decorated with embroidered dark red dragons here.
You can go south and out.
stop
You press a button to cancel the current autopilot program.
Proper in-sector coordinates not reached.  AutoVector program aborted.
[0m[Miriani] Kitty Mars wraps her arms around you.[0m
mir
[0m#SESSION 'StarConquest' ACTIVATED.[0m
ftl 275
The computer announces, "Setting course to Artifact Beacon Alpha 275."
Something deep inside the starship roars to life as the lights dim sharply.
A wormhole suddenly appears in front of the ship, its edges tinged an unusual
deep purple. Strange undulating shapes are half-visible deep inside it.
A thick undulating mist suddenly seems to rush toward the starship from every
direction, quickly blotting out the stars. Random shapes, some half-familiar,
occasionally form in the mist only to disappear almost immediately.
[0m[Miriani] Kitty Mars says to you, "you know I would have so loved that because I
felt so rejected by you."[0m
The starship has left a unique area of space.
A formless mist suddenly swirls outside the viewports, then is rapidly sucked
forward into a bright wormhole in front of the ship. The wormhole blinks out of
existence, and the ship is suddenly in normal space.
The computer announces, "Autotravel destination reached."
ships
There are no other ships in the sector.

[League Rapid Recharging Eatery & Battery-Powered Rest Station; Docking Bay]
A small, basic docking bay is the core of the station, along with the life
support system and resource storage. Small hatches lead to the other station
modules.

Apple", the four-person combat support carrier "Future Crimes", the one-person
runabout "Graceful In Flight", the one-person runabout "Pet My Tail, Cause

"Celestial Explorer" are parked here.

[0m#SESSION 'StarConquest' ACTIVATED.[0m
l
[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A small rectangular transparisteel viewport provides a view out
the front of the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for
the large starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the
viewport is the main control board, providing essential functions like the
shipwide power lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up
and folded back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses
overhead as needed. There is not really enough room for anyone to comfortably
stand here; there is only room for the pilot's chair and the controls arranged
around it. Most of the space aboard the small shuttle is dedicated to cargo.
Lights overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is at League Rapid Recharging Eatery &
Battery-Powered Rest Station; Docking Bay.
You see a bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Starseekers", a wormhole
drive tracer, a glossy silvery gray ceramic felo chow bowl, and a silky cerulean
cushion decorated with embroidered dark red dragons here.
You can go south and out.

modules.

runabout "Graceful In Flight", the one-person runabout "Pet My Tail, Cause
That's All You'll See", the luxury sightseer "Hummingbird's Migration", the
one-person runabout "Free Spirit", the one-person runabout "Hawthorne's
Sharp-shinned Hawk", the one-person runabout "Sincap", the one-person runabout
"Highland Sprinter", the one-person runabout "Jammer", and the luxury sightseer
"Celestial Explorer" are parked here.

[0m#SESSION 'StarConquest' ACTIVATED.[0m
l
[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A small rectangular transparisteel viewport provides a view out
the front of the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for
the large starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the
viewport is the main control board, providing essential functions like the
shipwide power lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up
and folded back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses
overhead as needed. There is not really enough room for anyone to comfortably
stand here; there is only room for the pilot's chair and the controls arranged
around it. Most of the space aboard the small shuttle is dedicated to cargo. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is at League Rapid Recharging Eatery &
Battery-Powered Rest Station; Docking Bay.
You see a bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Starseekers", a wormhole
drive tracer, a glossy silvery gray ceramic felo chow bowl, and a silky cerulean
cushion decorated with embroidered dark red dragons here.
You can go south and out.
out
out

AutoStar (general-purpose starship autopilot) Version 9.1

Destinations in this sector:
   Artifacts:

now aimed at 270.0, 0.0.

[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Airlock]
You see a large secure xenology storage container, a row of flightlockers, a
glossy red ceramic felo chow bowl, and an early warning space defense device
here.
You can go enter into the ship.
cycle
You press a large button marked CYCLE.
The computer announces, "Person detected without complete spacesuit. Cycling
will not proceed."
use shooting
You are not currently wearing a spacesuit. Do you wish to suit up now?
[Enter `yes' or `no']
y
You remove spacesuit components from a black flightbag with a red shooting star
on the side and quickly don them.
[0m[Miriani] From a thick black leather utility belt with several loops on it, you
hear a blue flight control scanner announce, "Flight control in Outreach, a Hale
starship is firing at a Hale starship."[0m
out
You may not leave the ship until the airlock's environment matches the external
environment.
cycle
You press a large button marked CYCLE.
The computer announces, "Beginning cycling."
A small light on the airlock control panel turns from green to yellow. Through
your suit, you hear the hiss of air quickly leaving the airlock.
The hiss of air slowly fades away into nothingness, and the yellow light becomes
red.

[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Airlock]
You see a large secure xenology storage container, a row of flightlockers, a
glossy red ceramic felo chow bowl, and an early warning space defense device
here.
You can go enter into the ship.
You float close to the luxury sightseer "Celestial Explorer", open the hatch,
and carefully float inside, orienting yourself so that your feet hit the floor
as you enter the ship's artificial gravity field.
cycle
You press a large button marked CYCLE.
A small light on the airlock control panel turns from red to yellow. Through
your suit, you gradually begin to hear the hiss of air entering the airlock.
enter
You may not leave the airlock while it is cycling.
The hiss of air slowly fades away into nothingness, and the yellow light becomes
green.

You float close to the luxury sightseer "Celestial Explorer", open the hatch,
and carefully float inside, orienting yourself so that your feet hit the floor
as you enter the ship's artificial gravity field.

your suit, you gradually begin to hear the hiss of air entering the airlock.

A small light on the airlock control panel turns from green to yellow. Through
your suit, you hear the hiss of air quickly leaving the airlock.
The hiss of air slowly fades away into nothingness, and the yellow light becomes
red.
out

[Deep Space]
The vacuum of space seems oddly peaceful now that it surrounds you. It is not
deep black as you expected, but seems to be filled with a diffuse glow. Stars
glint all around you, stunningly bright and sharp with no atmosphere or
vacuum-protected glass to distort their light. A wide smear of stars fills one
area of the sky, pointing the way Coreward.

The hiss of air slowly fades away into nothingness, and the yellow light becomes
red.
out
Are you sure you wish to leave the ship for a spacewalk?

your suit, you gradually begin to hear the hiss of air entering the airlock.
The hiss of air slowly fades away into nothingness, and the yellow light becomes
green.

[0m#SESSION 'StarConquest' ACTIVATED.[0m
l
[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A small rectangular transparisteel viewport provides a view out
the front of the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for
the large starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the
viewport is the main control board, providing essential functions like the
shipwide power lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up
and folded back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses
overhead as needed. There is not really enough room for anyone to comfortably
stand here; there is only room for the pilot's chair and the controls arranged
around it. Most of the space aboard the small shuttle is dedicated to cargo.
Lights overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in space.
You see a bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Starseekers", a wormhole
drive tracer, a glossy silvery gray ceramic felo chow bowl, and a silky cerulean
cushion decorated with embroidered dark red dragons here.
You can go south and out.

You make a selection on the AutoVector control board.

l
[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A small rectangular transparisteel viewport provides a view out
the front of the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for
the large starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the
viewport is the main control board, providing essential functions like the
shipwide power lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up
and folded back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses
overhead as needed. There is not really enough room for anyone to comfortably
stand here; there is only room for the pilot's chair and the controls arranged
around it. Most of the space aboard the small shuttle is dedicated to cargo.
Lights overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in space.
You see a bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Starseekers", a wormhole
drive tracer, a glossy silvery gray ceramic felo chow bowl, and a silky cerulean
cushion decorated with embroidered dark red dragons here.
You can go south and out.

ftl 275
The computer announces, "Setting course to Artifact Beacon Alpha 275."
Something deep inside the starship roars to life as the lights dim sharply.
A wormhole suddenly appears in front of the ship, its edges tinged an unusual
deep purple. Strange undulating shapes are half-visible deep inside it.
A thick undulating mist suddenly seems to rush toward the starship from every
direction, quickly blotting out the stars. Random shapes, some half-familiar,
occasionally form in the mist only to disappear almost immediately.
The starship has left a unique area of space.
[0m05:01[0m
The computer beeps in an imperative manner and informs you that the starship's
sensors have detected a new location of interest in the riftflow.
The starship has entered a unique area of space.
Bits of starships of alien design and other assorted junk litter space in this
area. Oddly, judging from some of the debris that the ship can detect in the
distance, this was the site not only of a naval battle but of some sort of
space-based infantry engagement.
A formless mist suddenly swirls outside the viewports, then is rapidly sucked
forward into a bright wormhole in front of the ship. The wormhole blinks out of
existence, and the ship is suddenly in normal space.
The computer announces, "Autotravel destination reached."
ships
There are no other ships in the sector.

glossy red ceramic felo chow bowl, and an early warning space defense device
here.
You can go enter into the ship.
You float close to the luxury sightseer "Celestial Explorer", open the hatch,
and carefully float inside, orienting yourself so that your feet hit the floor
as you enter the ship's artificial gravity field.
cycle
You press a large button marked CYCLE.
A small light on the airlock control panel turns from red to yellow. Through
your suit, you gradually begin to hear the hiss of air entering the airlock.
enter
You may not leave the airlock while it is cycling.
enter
You may not leave the airlock while it is cycling.
The hiss of air slowly fades away into nothingness, and the yellow light becomes
green.
enter

drive tracer, a glossy silvery gray ceramic felo chow bowl, and a silky cerulean
cushion decorated with embroidered dark red dragons here.

A small light on the airlock control panel turns from green to yellow. Through
your suit, you hear the hiss of air quickly leaving the airlock.
The hiss of air slowly fades away into nothingness, and the yellow light becomes
red.

[0m[Miriani] [Transport Pod 5676 to Acrylon] (indoors)[0m
[0m[Miriani] You see nowhere obvious to go.[0m
[0m[Miriani] You feel the gentle pull of acceleration as the pod lifts off.[0m
[0m[Miriani] You hear a sharp whine as the wormhole drive activates.[0m
[0m[Miriani] The pod vibrates slightly as it nears the wormhole's event horizon.[0m
[0m[Miriani] A bright blue light floods the room as the pod begins traveling
through the wormhole.[0m
[0m[Miriani] The bright light abruptly vanishes as the pod emerges from the
wormhole.[0m
[0m[Miriani] The sound of the pod's engine suddenly fills the area as the pod
begins moving toward its destination.[0m

[Deep Space]
The vacuum of space seems oddly peaceful now that it surrounds you. It is not
deep black as you expected, but seems to be filled with a diffuse glow. Stars
glint all around you, stunningly bright and sharp with no atmosphere or
vacuum-protected glass to distort their light. A wide smear of stars fills one
area of the sky, pointing the way Coreward.

[Deep Space]
The vacuum of space seems oddly peaceful now that it surrounds you. It is not
deep black as you expected, but seems to be filled with a diffuse glow. Stars
glint all around you, stunningly bright and sharp with no atmosphere or
vacuum-protected glass to distort their light. A wide smear of stars fills one
area of the sky, pointing the way Coreward.
You can go in any direction using a spacejet.

[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Airlock]
You see a large secure xenology storage container, a row of flightlockers, a
glossy red ceramic felo chow bowl, and an early warning space defense device
here.
You can go enter into the ship.
You float close to the luxury sightseer "Celestial Explorer", open the hatch,
and carefully float inside, orienting yourself so that your feet hit the floor
as you enter the ship's artificial gravity field.

green.
